revision.text:
{{Infobox military person |honorific_prefix = |name =William Stone Hubbell |honorific_suffix = |native_name = |native_name_lang = |image =US-MOH-1862.png |image_size =150px |alt = |caption = |birth_date ={{Birth date|1837|4|19}} |death_date ={{Death date and age|1930|8|28|1837|4|19}} |birth_place =[[Wolcottville, Connecticut|Wolcottville]] ([[Litchfield County, Connecticut|Litchfield County]]), [[Connecticut]] |death_place = |placeofburial =Indian Hill Cemetery, [[Middletown, Connecticut]] |placeofburial_label = |placeofburial_coordinates = |nickname = |birth_name = |allegiance =[[United States|United States of America]]
[[Union (American Civil War)|Union]] |branch =[[United States Army]]
[[Union Army]] |serviceyears = |rank =[[Major]] |servicenumber = |unit = [[21st Connecticut Infantry Regiment|21st Connecticut Volunteer Infantry Regiment]] |commands = |battles =[[American Civil War]] *[[Battle of Chaffin's Farm]] |battles_label = |awards =[[Medal of Honor]] |relations = |laterwork = |signature = |website = }} '''William Stone Hubbell''' (April 19, 1837 – August 28, 1930) was a [[United States Army]] captain during the [[American Civil War]], and a recipient of the [[Medal of Honor]]. ==Biography== Hubbell entered army service at [[North Stonington, Connecticut|North Stonington]] ([[New London County, Connecticut|New London County]]), Connecticut.{{Cite web |publisher = [[United States Army Center of Military History]] |title = Civil War Medal of Honor recipients (A-L) |work = Medal of Honor citations |date = August 6, 2009 |url = http://www.history.army.mil/html/moh/civwaral.html |accessdate = July 1, 2010}} Captain Hubbell served in Company A of the [[21st Connecticut Infantry Regiment|21st Connecticut Infantry]][http://www.sots.ct.gov/RegisterManual/SectionX/MEDALOFHONOR.htm Secretary of State, State of Connecticut] at the [[Battle of Chaffin's Farm]]. In that battle on September 30, 1864, at [[Fort Harrison, Virginia|Fort Harrison]], [[Virginia]], he led out a small flanking party, engaged a [[Confederate States Army|Confederate]] force and at great risk captured a large number of prisoners.[http://www.homeofheroes.com/gravesites/states/pages_go/hubbell_william.html Home of Heroes] For this action, Hubbell was awarded the Medal of Honor on June 13, 1894. William Stone Hubbell died on August 28, 1930. He is buried in Indian Hill Cemetery, [[Middletown, Connecticut]].{{Find a Grave|19612|work=Claim to Fame: Medal of Honor recipients|accessdate=September 6, 2010}} ==Medal of Honor citation== Rank and organization: Captain, Company A, 21st Connecticut Infantry. Place and date: At Fort Harrison, Va., September 30, 1864. Entered service at: North Stonington, Conn. Born: April 19, 1837, Wolcottville, Conn. Date of issue: June 13, 1894. '''Citation:'''
Led out a small flanking party and by a clash and at great risk captured a large number of prisoners.
==See also== {{Portal|Biography|United States Army|American Civil War}} *[[List of American Civil War Medal of Honor recipients: G–L#H|List of American Civil War Medal of Honor recipients: G–L]] *[[William Spring Hubbell]] (1801–1873), American politician, congressman from New York ==Notes== {{Reflist}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Hubbell, William Stone}} [[Category:1837 births]] [[Category:1930 deaths]] [[Category:United States Army Medal of Honor recipients]] [[Category:People of Connecticut in the American Civil War]] [[Category:Union Army officers]] [[Category:American Civil War recipients of the Medal of Honor]] [[Category:Military personnel from Connecticut]]
